column1: Sandusky  is a city in the U.S. state of Ohio and the county seat of Erie County. Situated in northern Ohio on the shores of Lake Erie
column2: Sandusky is midway between Toledo to the west and Cleveland to the east.

column9: Cedar Point. Cedar Point has one of the largest collections of roller coasters in the world and is widely regarded as one of the best amusement parks. Cedar Point includes 17 roller coasters.The National Arbor Day Foundation has designated Sandusky as a Tree City USA.

column1: The accepted etymology is that the name "Sandusky" is derived from the Wyandot word saundustee
column3: "cold water." In his 1734 history of New France
column4: Charlevoix transliterated the word as "Chinouski."  Sandusky Bay
column5: formed at the mouth of the Sandusky River
column6: is identified as "Lac (Lake) Sandouské" on a 1718 map by Guillaume DeLisle. The name "L.(Lac) Sandoski" appears on a 1733 map. Sandusky Bay was also called Lac Ondaské
column7: in another French transliteration of the Wyandot.The river and bay gave rise to a number of eponymous forts and settlements along their shores. These consisted of the short-lived English trading post Fort Sandusky north of the bay
column8: the French Fort Sandoské that replaced it
column9: the British Fort Sandusky on the south shore of the bay
column10: the American Fort Sandusky (later Fort Stephenson) upriver at Lower Sandusky (now known as Fremont
column12: as well as the Wyandot Indian village of Upper Sandusky farther upriver.Another
column13: less accepted etymologic version claims that the city’s name goes back to an American trader and frontiersman named Anthony Sadowski
column14: a neighbor of the Boone family and co-founder of Amity village. He was employed by the governor of then British Pennsylvania as a trader and interpreter
column16: especially Iroquois. He moved to the Pennsylvania frontier in January 1712 and could easily have made it to Lake Erie by 1718 to establish a federal trading post. One genealogical line of his descendants are actually called “Sandusky”.

column1: This area was a center of trading and fortifications since the 18th century: the English
column3: and Americans had trading posts and forts built on both the north and south sides of Sandusky Bay. George Groghan was one of the more prominent men who operated in this area in the 18th-century.

column1: Development by European Americans of the city of Sandusky
column3: on the southeast shore of Sandusky Bay
column4: followed settlement of the war of 1812. Part of the city quickly enveloped the site of an earlier small village named "Portland" (established about 1816). Sandusky was incorporated as a city in 1824. Eventually the city of Sandusky encompassed most of the entire township that had been called Portland. Some of the city was built on land formerly occupied by a Native American man named Ogontz
column5: and therefore the city is said to have been built on "Ogontz' place".

column1: Sandusky's rise in the 19th-century was heavily influenced by its location at the head of Sandusky Bay. This made it a key point both for the movement of goods and for the movement of people. The mild climate caused by its proximity to Lake Erie also caused it to become the center of Ohio's wine industry. The presence of limestone was also key to its development. It was also a key location for ice harvesting in the 19th-century. Lumber transport
column2: stone quarrying and in the early 20th-century manufacturing have all been key in the city's history.

column1: Prior to the abolition of slavery in the United States
column2: Sandusky was a major stop for refugee slaves on the Underground Railroad
column3: as some would travel across Lake Erie to reach freedom in Canada. Although Ohio was a free state
column4: they felt at risk from slavecatchers because of bonuses offered under the Fugitive Slave Act of 1850. As depicted in Harriet Beecher Stowe's novel Uncle Tom's Cabin (1855)
column5: many refugee slaves seeking to get to Canada made their way to Sandusky
column6: where they boarded boats crossing Lake Erie to the port of Amherstburg in Ontario.

column1: Sandusky's original plat was designed by surveyor Hector Kilbourne according to a modified grid plan
column2: known today as the Kilbourne Plat. Kilbourne later became the first Worshipful Master of the first Sandusky Masonic Lodge known as Science Lodge #50
column3: still in operation on Wayne Street. His design featured a street grid with avenues cutting diagonally to create patterns reminiscent of the symbols of Freemasonry.
Sandusky was the site of groundbreaking for the Mad River and Lake Erie Railroad
column4: which brought change to the town. Industrial areas developed near the railroad and goods were transported through the port. The coal docks located west of downtown still use a portion of the original MR&LE right-of-way. In 1838 Erie County
column5: Ohio was formed by the state legislature and Sandusky was designated the county seat. This lead to the foundation of a court house and Sandusky becoming a regional government center. In 1846 Sandusky had a population of approximately 3
column6: 000 people. At that point Sandusky had two railroads and was also a main focus of lake traffic. The town then consisted of many stores
column7: two printing offices
column12: and several iron furnaces.Since the late 20th century
column13: Battery Park Marina was developed on the original site of the MR&LE Railroad  after restructuring of the industry reduced traffic on the line. The tracks that ran through downtown Sandusky have since been removed. Most of the downtown industrial area is also being redeveloped for other purposes

column1: Sandusky has a humid continental climate (Köppen climate classification Dfa)
column2: typical of the Midwestern United States
column3: with warm summers and cold winters. Winters tend to be cold
column4: with an average January high temperature of 32 °F (0 °C)
column5: and an average January low temperature of 19 °F (−7 °C)
column6: with considerable variation in temperatures. Sandusky averages 23.3 inches (591.8 mm) of snow per winter. Summers tend to be warm with an average July high temperature of 82 °F (28 °C)
column7: and an average July low temperature of 66 °F (19 °C). Summer weather is more stable
column8: generally humid with thunderstorms. Fall usually is the driest season with many clear warm days and cool nights.

column1: The highest recorded temperature in Sandusky of 105 °F (41 °C) was set on July 14
column3: and the lowest recorded temperature of −20 °F (−29 °C) was set on January 19

column3: boating
column4: and more recently by its many indoor and outdoor water parks. It is also noted for being the location of the (fictional) "Callahan Auto Parts" in the movie Tommy Boy.

column3: a wooden roller coaster
column4: was built and named for the local high school's mascot. It is currently the park's oldest operating roller coaster. In the latter half of the twentieth century
column5: Cedar Point shattered countless roller coaster records with rides like Corkscrew (first coaster with three or more inversions)
column6: Gemini (tallest and fastest roller coaster in the world when constructed in 1978)
column7: Magnum XL-200 (tallest and fastest roller coaster in the world when constructed in 1989)
column8: Mean Streak (tallest and fastest wooden roller coaster in the world when constructed in 1991)

column10: and Mantis (tallest and fastest stand-up roller coaster in the world when constructed in 1996).

column3: at 310 feet (94 m) tall
column4: and 93 miles per hour (150 km/h) top speed. In 2003
column5: Cedar Point debuted Top Thrill Dragster. When it was built it was the tallest (420 ft or 130 m) and the fastest (120 mph or 190 km/h) roller coaster in the world. Cedar Point brought its roller coaster total to 17 in 2007 with the construction of Maverick. The park has been known for several years for having the most roller coasters and amusement rides in the world. It has long been nicknamed "America's Roller Coast". It has also been ranked the best amusement park in the world by the Golden Ticket Awards for 15 consecutive years. In 2013
column6: Cedar Point added a 16th coaster called Gatekeeper. It broke records for the tallest

column9: and steepest winged coaster as of 2013.

column1: Sandusky Transit System (STS) runs a full-service transit system across the Greater Sandusky Area. Its main station is in the heart of downtown on the corner of Washington St. and Wayne St.

column3: provides service to Sandusky. There are four trains daily
column4: all arriving in the late night/early morning hours: the Capitol Limited between Chicago and Washington
column5: D.C.
column6: via Pittsburgh; and the Lake Shore Limited between Chicago and New York/Boston via Buffalo. There is also an ongoing (as of January 2011) study into the possibility of commuter rail to Cleveland.A Greyhound Lines bus station is located on Route 101 at Route 2 south of Sandusky in Margaretta Township.

column1: The regional airport is 18 minutes outside of the city. It serves the City Of Sandusky and the greater regional area.

column1: Sandusky (along with nearby Port Clinton and the Lake Erie Islands - known in the region collectively as "Vacationland") is served by a daily newspaper
column3: and ten local radio stations. BAS Broadcasting (based in nearby Fremont) owns and operates WCPZ FM 102.7 (hot AC)
column4: WMJK FM 100.9 (country)
column5: WOHF FM 92.1 (classic hits)
column6: WFRO-FM FM 99.1 (AC)
column7: and WLEC AM 1450 (oldies/standards).Religious stations include WVMS FM 89.5 (run by the Moody Bible Institute as a relay of WCRF FM in Cleveland) and WGGN FM 97.7 which plays contemporary Christian music
column8: in addition to WHRQ 88.1 FM (as a repeater of WNOC "Annunciation Radio" based in Toledo) airing programming from EWTN Global Catholic Radio.

column1: Elyria-Lorain Broadcasting Co. operates three stations serving the "Vacationland" region

column4: religiously-oriented WGGN-TV channel 52 (DTV 3). Sandusky's location between Toledo and Cleveland means that the city is also served by stations (albeit at a fringe level) in both of those markets as well.
